result.title: Objective
result.description: To establish and operationalize terrestrial PAs in the Dulombi-BoÃ©-Tchetche (DBT) complex and thereby significantly expand and strengthen Guinea-Bissauâ€™s PA system.

target.comment: Classificação das AP do Complexo DBT e aumento da Cobertura do SNAP de 14,9 para 26 % do território nacional

actual.comment: Progress being made towards the creation “ de jure” of the protected areas within DBT Complex as follows: consolidated management structures are in place in all project sites; inventory of fauna, including forestry and aquatic avifauna, flora completed as well as the fauna and flora management plans; legal and regulatory texts discussed and approved by key actors; prior examination of the complex DBT project classification as type C carried out by CAIA (Environmental Impact Evaluation Unit); International Consultant (Firm) to carry out a study on environmental and socio-economic impact assessment of DBT parks creation selected; preliminary DBT parks management plans developed and available; strategic plan for expansion of the National Protected Area System under preparation; Business plan available; Wendo tcham lagoon designated as Humid Zone of international importance by the RAMSAR Convention.

target.comment: Decréscimo da taxa de deflorestação no Complexo DBT, expresso em ha de floresta densa e de floresta aberta

actual.comment: DBT Complex zone completely preserved from illegal logging; 30 Village Fire Management Committees were established and are fully operational. There is also a reduced pressure on the forest from the peasants as a result of alternative sustainable solutions/technologies opportunities offered, for: (i) Rice production in swamp soils instead of upland soils by 147 peasants and their respective family members (in average, 8 per household), (ii) 247 people learned how to build improved cook stoves, most efficient in terms of energy (fuel wood) consumption/saving; (iii) Improved beekeeping techniques learnt and adopted by 120 beekeepers; (iv) Reforestation (20 ha expected more for this year) and (v) Increased awareness given to the village hunters on the damage that can result from burning land for creating new grazing land.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: 3. The status of emblematic species such as the African elephant in the Dulombi NP and the western Chimpanzees in the BoÃ© area

baseline.comment:
According to recent survey by Chimbo Foundation, there are approximately 500 chimp individuals in the BoÃ© area.
Elephant survey will require update.

target.comment: Populations of emblematic species maintained stable

actual.comment:
Following the MTR recommendation, one indicator has been adopted: Chimpanzees. It is estimated that the current population is stable and is about 800 individuals, according to Chimbo Foundation estimates. There is a considerable increase of other primate species, and ungulates, due to considerable decrease of hunting activities in the complex as a result of the supervision by DBT Park-Guards, awareness and fear of contamination of zoonosis and in particular of the Ebola virus.
Effective compliance with the protection of wildlife is having positive effects on the growth of different species. It is observed that the elephant population is very small and given their cross-border migration it is difficult to carry out effective follow-up. Observations of other emblematic species are very frequent like the Hippo in the Corubal River and Red Antelope (Hippotragus equinus) in all DBT Complex sites. Furthermore, signs of the presence of Lions (Panthera) were also observed in Boé.

result.title: Outcome 1
result.description: Immediate threats to terrestrial ecosystems mitigated through the effective expansion and management of PAs in the forest belt region

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: 4. Increased scores on the GEF4â€™s PA Management Effectiveness Tracking Tool â€œMETTâ€ for all five target sites within the DBT Complex

baseline.comment:
[1] Dulombi NP 19
[2] BoÃ© NP 20
[3] Cuntabane-Quebo Corr. 19
[4] Salifo Corridor 19
[5] Tchetche Corridor 21

target.comment:
All scores are 30 by the MTE
All scores are 40 by end of project

actual.comment:
According to the METT criterion as defined in the project document, the score below shows that there is improvement in the management of the DBT Complex.
The METT values continue improving within the DBT Complex, and the biggest threats are being efficiently managed by the project sites management structure, actively presents in the project sites with high support of the key local actors (farmers, hunters, traditional chiefs, CBOs leaders and local administrative officials). The increase in the awareness of these project partners/beneficiaries has contributed for the conservation of PA forest ecosystems (its fauna and flora) by mobilizing communities against illegal logging and encouraging its members to abandon/reduce slash and burn practices for agriculture purpose, use of fire in traditional beekeeping and harmful illegal hunting (poisoning animals, burn forest to stimulate grass regeneration). Furthermore, this has contributed for controlling new settlements within the PAs for a minimal level in the buffer zones of the parks from migration of people from across the border. Although the Angolan bauxite mining concession is outside the proposed PAs, there is still a concern about the impacts of transporting the ore via rail or road through the Cuntabane-Quebo Wildlife Corridor to the Buba sea port for export and the impacts of future mining activities on the watershed of the Corubal River Basin, critical to the region. The modification of the natural ecosystem by fires of different origins persists but in minor scale. The causes of the fires are being actively discussed, and the measures widely disseminated through socio-professional associations/CBOs of farmers and hunters, youths and women covering all the extent of the DBT Complex. Evasive species, pollution and major geological events (except for the siltation of some rivers, streams and springs) are unknown. Best traditional conservation management practices are being revitalized with the support of village community volunteers, leaders and authorities.
Dulombi: 65
Boé: 62
Tche-tche: 61
Cuntabane-Quebo: 61
Salifo-Xitole: 60
Average: 61,6

result.title: Outcome 2
result.description: Improved systemic and institutional capacity provides the enabling framework for establishing and managing a more representative PA network.

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: 5. Increased scores on the UNDPâ€™s Capacity Development Scorecard for Protected Areas Management over the baseline

target.comment: Scores, expressed in absolute terms, increase by at least 20%

actual.comment: The Capacity Development Scorecard (CDS) tool measure the improvement of the capacities of the actors involved in the management of the PA. It has been applied in the formulation of the project in 2009. It takes into account the systemic level (DBT complex as a whole), the institutional level (entities involved), and the individual level. During the project Mid-Term Evaluation exercise, the CDS has been applied to measure the evolution in the development of capacity-building since the launch of the project. The results of the mid-term evaluation are: systemic 20/30 (64%) Institutional 29/45 (63%) Individual 10/21 (52%) (Average general 61%). While training needs assessment has not been performed at the start of the project, the current technical, human and logistic capacities of IBAP have been strengthened. IBAP’s cadres have benefitted from relevant training provided on PA management, SIG, strategic planning, micro projects formulation, PA creation process that contributed to increase their awareness and capacity to fulfil their duties. According to the MTR report, efforts have to be dedicated in upgrading the staff technical capacity for which a capacity development plan must be prepared and implemented. In addition to that, development of sustainable mechanism of financing the National Protected Area System management cost must be ensured.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: 6. Results from the application of UNDPâ€™s Financial Sustainability Scorecard

baseline.comment: Total Score for PA System = 40 out of a total possible score of 197 (i.e. 20%)

target.comment: Scores, expressed in absolute terms, increase by at least 30%

actual.comment:
The financial sustainability scorecard (FSC) measures the financial sustainability of the management of the PA. It was applied in 2009 to the National system of protected (SNAP) areas during the project document formulation (at the same time as the METT). It was revised in June 2012, and then in 2014. The mid-term evaluation team has analyzed all of the FSC made by the various IBAP projects. The scores obtained differs much from one to the other FSC. The team concluded that IBAP’s need to harmonize its monitoring system at a centralized level (e.g. at level of IBAP financial unit) in order to have a more credible consolidated tool.
The results of the mid-term evaluation are: total score of 74 out 220, or 34%.

result.title: Outcome 3
result.description: Participatory conservation management approaches in the DBT Complex are implemented.

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: 7. Communitiesâ€™ perception of their livelihood stake in the good stewardship of biological resources in the DBT Complex, measured through the periodic and independent application of the â€˜Most Significant Changeâ€™ (MSC) technique.

baseline.comment:
Not Applicable
The MSC technique is to be applied once the project has been launched and some form of change has occurred. The baseline corresponds to all assessments that corroborate the situation analysis for this project, particularly with respect to land-uses and livelihoods.

target.comment: Changes in livelihoods are perceived through the independent application of the MSC technique

actual.comment: Through the MSC, it was verified improvement in the perception that the ”parks are with and for the populations" to decide on the rights of use and access in the areas of sustainable development within the Park; it’s important to reinforce their traditional social mechanisms of control and management of space and natural resources, as well as taking into account their heritage, knowledge, norms and cultural practices regarding management of the PA of the DBT complex; the information, awareness and training of policy makers provided have led to a positive change in perception of the role and function of the protected areas in biodiversity conservation for economic and socio-cultural activities support, climate change mitigation, food security and poverty reduction.

iati-activity.title: Climate Change Adaptation

iati-activity.title: Climate Change Adaptation
iati-activity.description: Guinea-Bissau's agrarian and water sectors resilience and daptive capacity to climate change stregnthgened at national, regional and community levels (14 villages with 11,000 inhabitants).

result.title: Objective
result.description: To increase resilience and enhance key adaptive capacity to address the additional risks posed by climate change to water and agriculture sectors in Guinea- Bissau

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: 1. High level policies and management plans relating to agriculture and water sectors explicitly consider climate change risks and opportunities

baseline.comment:
The following policies / plans are not climate-proof:
*National Plan of Agricultural Investment (PNIA)
*National Program on Food Security
*Water Directive / Water Code
*Poverty Reduction Strategy II

target.comment: At least two high level policies (National Plan for Agricultural Investimment, Region Gabu Local Plan Development, Water and Sanitation Policies, National Plan Livestock development) / management plans explicitly consider climate change risks and opportunities.

actual.comment: . Significant progress has been made towards the achievement of this DO target: (i) 40 keys cadres from 16 keys line ministers have acquired knowledge on climate change mainstreaming methodology and have actively participated in the application of the methodology, integrating CC issues into the target policy documents and plans (Agricultural Development Policy Letter; Water and Sanitation Master Plan; Livestock Development Policy Letter; National Strategy for Poverty Reduction and Gabu Region Local Development Plans (Piche and Pirada administrative sectors). These documents have been revised integrating climate changes issues, following the validation workshops held in Bissau and Gabu. Is expected that by the end of the year this policy documents and plans will be adopted by the Government.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: 2.Government and international funding allocated to managing climate change risks increased

actual.comment:
The project team (National Project Coordinator, Agricultural Specialist and Climate Change Adaptation Specialist) has provided assistance to the Government in its partnership with: (a) West African Development Bank (BOAD) for a project proposal formulation on climate change adaptation in amount of 10,000,000 USD to the Board of Adaptation Fund before end of the year; (b) European Union (under Global Climate Changes Alliance-GCCA funding) for formulation of project proposal on adaptation and mitigation to climate in order to strengthen the resilience of communities of the Bafatá, Gabu, Quinara and Tombali regions. This project is in its final stage and the planned funding are of 4 million euros and is virtually guaranteed. This project, will strengthen the adaptation initiatives envisaged under the current NAPA-Resilience project in the Gabu region.
UNDP CO and Regional Technical Advisor have provided technical support to the Government in the elaboration of a 12.5 million USD project proposal on climate change adaptation in coastal area and a 5 million USD project proposal on early warning system development. The adaptation project was approved but as LDCF is exhaust, therefore these two projects are under reformulation seeking GCF funding.
Within the framework of partnership with the Directorate General of Livestock, the Government through Monetary Union of West Africa (UEMOA) has provided 25,000 USD for the vaccination of cattle against carbuncle hematic and symptomatic. Also, under the same framework, 25,000 USD were invested in the construction of 4 veterinary clinics, 1 small slaughterhouse and 1 butcher shop in some of the project targeted villages in Gabu Region.
These two initiatives will support the achievement of the target under this DO.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: 3. Scores of UNDP\\\'s Vulnerability Reduction Assessment (VRA) to be applied upon inception, mid-term and end-of-project in project-site communities

baseline.comment: As of results after the application of the tool at project inception

actual.comment: The exposure to the risks are the same but the vulnerability of the communities has decreased thanks to increase of awareness on climate change issues and the adoption of sustainable solutions/technologies such as cereal banks, fodder plants cultivation, resilient agricultural techniques, improved wells for water adduction/pumping, etc. during the reporting period, the following has contributed for strengthening the communities resilience to climate change: (i) draft report identifying keys national actors suitable to address climate risks management and proposing a Commitment Plan for climate risks management to be signed by all of them is available; (ii) 10 Contingencies Plans for 10 villages are developed and adopted; (iii) four (4) national technicians have acquired knowledge on climate change risks and vulnerability analysis and mainstreaming methodology through a training course provided by a Burkina Faso Specialized Training Institute; (v) the Rural Forum on Climate Change and the Environmental Surveillance Committee has met quarterly and promoted awareness campaigns on Ebola Virus Disease, deforestation implications in climate change, need to preserve their natural heritage through a participatory and holistic approach.

result.title: Outcome 1
result.description: Climate change risks and adaptation measures integrated into key national policies, plans and programs for water, agriculture and livestock resource management.

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: 1. High level policies and management plans relating to agriculture and water sectors explicitly consider climate change risks and opportunities

baseline.comment:
The following policies / plans are not climate-proof:
*National Plan of Agricultural Investment (PNIA)
*National Program on Food Security
*Water Directive / Water Code
*Poverty Reduction Strategy II

target.comment: At least two policy frameworks relevant for the agriculture and water sectors effectively incorporate climate risk consideration and adaptation measures

actual.comment: This DO is in good trend for its accomplishement: 40 national technicians from key ministries trained on UNDP climate change mainstreaming methodology; revised and preliminary mainstreamed climate change issues into Agricultural Development Policy Letter, Water and Sanitation Master Plan, Livestock Development Policy Letter, and Gabu Region Local Development Plans (Pitche and Pirada administrative Sectors). 239 students from different schools in Gabu region sensitized on climate change issues.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: 2. Number of key agencies having taken institutional measures to respond to climate change through capacity building and mainstreaming activities

target.comment: MADR, MEIRN NMI has the capability and enhanced implementation and planning of the program and projects on climate change

actual.comment: The project support to the Government has contributed to (i) strengthen the capacity of the National Institute of the Meteorology (INM-GB) in the field of data processing and dissemination of meteorological information, (ii) improve INM-GB capacity to provide meteorological assistance supportive to various social and economic activities, namely agricultural production activities (iii) enable NIM-GB, to participate and profit from the World Meteorological Monitoring programme (VMM) and (iv) create a scientific basis for an early warning system development, (v) two (2) NIM-GB cadres trained in Praia (Cape Verde) on Geographical Information Systems to strengthen the GIS Laboratory in process of operationalization. This Laboratory also has received too equipments from the SEMA (System of Environmental Monitoring in Africa) Project in complementary basis.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: 3. Percentage of end users utilizing climate risk information from seasonal climate forecast systems in decision-making.

baseline.comment: No current seasonal climate forecast system is in place. Once in place for at least 6 months, a baseline in terms of potential and actual end-users will be set

target.comment: Results of the seasonal forecast and its integration into farming practices are available

actual.comment:
Synoptic and climatological stations of Bafata and Gabu inaugurated
Response kits delivered to operationalize of contingency plans in 10 villages, project sites
The pluviómetre peasants continue to play their roles, giving relevant information to farmers about the soil humidity.
Two local community radios continue to emit radio programs about meteorological information. The "Radio Sol Mansi" with national coverage has issued awareness programs "radio nóvelas" in three national languages (creolo, fula and mandinga), in order to sensitize the general population about causes, consequence, climate change impacts and adaptation measures.
A total of 10 Contingency Plans were prepared for 10 villages. Were delivered the kits for rapid response for the implementation of Contingency Plans in these 10 villages.
Performed more than 10 (ten) awareness campaigns in which they were sensitized about 400 people in villages on the operationalization of the Contingency Plans drawn up in 10 villages of the project whose objective aims to train teams to answer the possible calamities of natural disasters;
Formed 19 literacy teachers and animators, among which 2 are women, about the use and implementation of literacy teachers manual; Literate of literacy participants in 14 project villages sites were 331 (214 are women) on different themes; Conducted and presented a theatrical piece (play) about the problems of climate change and mitigation measures in the 9th FRAC session;

result.title: Outcome 2
result.description: Small and medium scale climate change adaptation practices for agriculture, water and livestock resource management are demonstrated and implemented in selected regions

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: 1. Average agricultural productivity of key crops (kg / ha), measured at site level in pilot demonstration fields - showing improvements compared to national and/or regional average for GabÃº

baseline.comment: National and/or regional (GabÃº) average agricultural productivity for key crops to be applied as baseline for comparison

target.comment: Increased the average yield of cereal crops dried (sorghum, black corn, corn Bacillus, etc.) approximately 200 kg /ha; pam-pam and bas fond rice of approximately 200-300 kg /ha

actual.comment: Formed 44 people (22 women and 22 men) of the Management Committee of water points in 11 locations. Built 6 drinking water supply wells; 6 animators trained in the techniques of determination of crop yields through square installation. Animators have used this knowledge in installing 53 square in 53 agricultural fields. Of these 17 were cultivated fields of traditional form and remaining through new techniques. Initiated the hidro-agricola management in Padjama, Canquelifa, Iancor, Cuntim; Formed and recycled a total of 361 farmers in agricultural producers about the cultural climate resilient techniques, of which 58 are women about 32.58%. Have been installed 30 demonstration fields practice (0.25 x 0.25 ha) being 13 of Zaï, 10 of crop rotation and 7 transverse field. The average yields were 2348 kg/ha for rice; 1293 kg/ha for corn. 1572 kg/ha black maize and 940 kg/ha for peanuts; Conducted 5 awareness-raising campaigns and information to communities about the use of excreta for the production of organic fertilizers and producing alternative energy source. In this campaign form 150 people that sensitized 80 are women. Trained 183 farmers in climate change resilient techniques. Finished the stake of approximately 546 hectares of land to practice agriculture; Sensitized 1350 new cattle breeders , in which 619 are women on the importance of brachiaria cultivation

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: 2. Food security in pilot villages as a result of the effective uptake of technologies and techniques introduced by the project

baseline.comment: As per WFP data for selected villages among target sites

target.comment: Guaranteed food availability / increased by at least two more months

actual.comment: Finalized the construction of 8 seeds/cereal banks with a storage capacity of 25 tons each, in 8 villages (Cuntim, Camalidja, Padjama, Canquelifa, Bajocunda, Patchana, and Copa Mangui) for storage of cereals and seeds;Sensitized 743 creators of cattle, of which 125 are women, about animal nutrition and importance of hangars; Formed 55 creators of cattle on the family cattle management; Formed 100 creators in animal housing techniques, its advantage in dairy and meat production; Built 23 hangars with storage capacity of 32.77 ton (1.425 ton/hangar) for storage of hay for livestock feed in the critical period (February to June), being 16 in 14 projects villages and 7 in the neighbouring villages; Harvested 600 kg of seeds of brachiaria in 27 fields installed the 24 villages are very common; Collected 50000 kg of dry straw of brachiaria in 27 fields and stored in hangars; 7000 kg of dry straw harvested and stored in hangars built for the purpose; Produced and distributed 6 tons of organic fertilizer (1.2 tonnes per village) by bovine waste recovery;

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: 3. Water availability at the level of households that are benefitting from pilot measures to improve water management (litres / day / inhabitant over time)

baseline.comment: Not available - target households for improved water management are not yet established

target.comment: Availability of 20 liters of water / head / day over time)

actual.comment: Inhabitants of 14 villages, project sites, have access to clean drinking water by building 14 water points (11 modern and improved wells 3 holes). This water availability is extensible to the animals that they have water in quantity and quality, thereby improving the public health situation. All these 14 villages have management committees of water spots composed essentially by women.

result.title: Outcome 3
result.description: Lessons learned and best practices from pilot activities are disseminated, and integrated in national plans and policies.

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: 1. Percentage of stakeholders being targeted for awareness-raising activities affirming ownership of adaptation processes

baseline.comment: N/A - stakeholders to be targeted for awareness-raising activities will be defined upon inception

actual.comment: The synergy with other projects involved area could be bring more impact, change and transformation in communities to strengthen their adaptive capacity to adverse effects of climate change; To maximize use of the holes is required near the holes are constructed with the respective troughs to serve not only for human consumption but also for animal; Given the financial difficulties widely known an important lesson was taken: the will to continue to work , prepare documents required for achieving the objectives set for the various products; It is possible to save, capitalize upon the financial resources of the projects, as well as expand the area of ??competence of the same , by creating synergy with other project stakeholders which would be beneficial for the people; The successful introduction of new technologies in agriculture depends on the strategy used, that is, must be accompanied by incentives to the agricultural inputs and materials; There is a great desire on the part of peasants trained to replicate the new techniques of resilient adaptation to climate. The need to expand the tuning fork of new technologies in the agricultural sector (agriculture, livestock and water management ) for farmers and creators of the project area and surrounding. This extension depends on the strategy used, that is, must be accompanied by incentives to the agricultural inputs and materials.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: 2. Number of contributions to the Adaptation Learning Mechanism (ALM)

actual.comment: With the constant updating and improving the project Web site interface (www.alteracoesclimaticas-gb.org), the establishment of the first BO, they were distributed 1000 copies whose contents causes and consequences of climate change and mitigation measures of its effects , and the issuance of radio novel and radio programs of the project, the project communities begin to learn best resilient adaptation techniques to climate change and now have information on the benefits of its application. They are shared several success stories both in terms of agriculture as the feed level ( e.g. introduction of forage spices - . Brachiaria ). Several success stories are filmed and will soon be made ??available to UNDP.

location.name: Bissau
location.activity-description: Le pays entire car les décideurs politiques et les cadres au niveau national seront formés. Les cadres de Bafatá, Gabú et Quinara sont ciblés au niveau régional. Les OCB et ONG nationales et régionales seront impliquées. La plupart d'activités se tiendront à Bissau.

iati-activity.title: Local governance and economic development project
iati-activity.description: The objective of this project is to enhance the capacity of national, regional and pre-municipalities authorities and to reinforce a inclusive and participatory planning in order to improve food security and reduce poverty.

iati-activity.title: Strengthening National PA System in Guinea-Bissau
iati-activity.description: The project will support the capitalization of biodiversity Trust Fund Bioguine Foundation and IBAP to effectively manage the National Protected Area System, particularly the management of the Castanhez National Park.

iati-activity.title: Strengthening National PA Syst
iati-activity.description: A sustainable financial mechanism will be in place supporting the National Protected Area System and IBAP's capacity to effectively manage the Cantanhez National Park will be reinforced through a comprehensive capacity development program implementation.
